Thus, among the Communists and their left-wing Socialist allies, 5J. per

Moving gradually from left to right across the political spectrum, DOXA

verse of the Communists and left Socialists. In this democratic, ieft-of-center

The contrast to the Communist viewpoint was even more striking among the
members or supporters of Italy*s biggest party, the Christian Democrats. Only
eight per cent of these believed the turning over of atomic secret© to Russia
by western scientists helped the cause of world peace. Uixty seven per cent
said this action increased the peril of war.
Among Liberals and monarchists, 10 per cent thought such a transfer of
secrets a contribution to peace and J1 per cent thought it increased the risk

To summarize this section of DOXA1® report to the magazine Homo, in the
camp of the Communists and their allies the idea that scientists who gave Russia
atomic secret® A&&X contributed to peace carried by a margin of five to one.
But in all other Italian parties taken together, the verdict was eight to one
that such scientists had increased the danger of another war.
DOXA also asked Italians this question: "Taking account of all factors —
human and technical — do you believe that from the military point of view,
Russia or America is the stronger today?" In Italy, a country allied with the
United States in the North Atlantic treaty organization, the overall results
were these:
Fifteen per cent said they believed Russia was the stronger and 32 per
cent said they thought the United States was the more powerful as of today.
But 30 per cent said they thought the strength of the two powerful nations was
about on par, and 22 per cent said they did not know.
The political party results were about as they had been on the previous
question: 41 per cent of the Communists and their allies said Russia was
stronger and only six per cent of this group picked the United States, with 33
per cent saying they thought the two powers were about equal. But among the
Christian Democrats, to take one other example, only six per cent said they
thought Russia was the stronger, m even 50 per cent said the United States
was the more powerful and 21 per cent said they believed the two powers were
about on par.
